remixlab.bias

Class BogusEvent

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.bias.BogusEvent
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Copyable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ClickEvent, KeyboardEvent, MotionEvent

    public class BogusEvent
extends Object
implements Copyable
    The root of all events that are to be handled by an Agent. Every BogusEvent encapsulates a Shortcut which may be bound to an user-defined action (see shortcut()). Gesture initialization and termination, which may be of the interest of Grabber objects, are reported by fired() and flushed(), respectively.

    The following are the main class specializations: MotionEvent, ClickEvent, and KeyboardEvent. Please refer to their documentation for details.

    If you ever need to define you're own bogus-event type, derive from this class, declare a shortcut type for your event (for details refer to the Shortcut), and override the shortcut() and get() methods. If your custom event class defines it's own attributes, its hashCode(), equals(Object) and get() methods should be overridden as well.

    Note BogusEvent detection/reduction could happened in several different ways. For instance, in the context of Java-based application, it typically takes place when implementing a mouse listener interface. In Processing, it does it when registering at the PApplet the so called mouseEvent and KeyEvent methods. Moreover, the Agent.handleFeed() provides a callback alternative when none of these mechanisms are available (as it often happens when dealing with specialized, non-default input hardware).

      • flush

        public BogusEvent flush()

        See Also:
        flushed()

      • fire

        public BogusEvent fire()
        Same as this.get() but sets the fired() flag to true. Only agents may call this.
        See Also:
        flushed()

      • flushed

        public boolean flushed()
        Returns true if this is a 'flushed' event. Flushed events indicate gesture termination, such as a mouse-release.
        See Also:
        fired()

      • fired

        public boolean fired()
        Returns true if this is a 'fired' event. Fired events indicate gesture activation, such as a mouse-press.
        See Also:
        flushed()
